title:
Metallakkumulation in Moosen: Standörtliche und regionale\ud
Randbedingungen des Biomonitoring von Luftverunreinigungen [Metal accumulation in mosses: local and regional boundary conditions of biomonitoring air pollution]
abstract:
Metal accumulation in mosses: Local and regional boundary\ud
conditions of biomonitoring air pollution\ud
Goal and Scope. Several studies show that the concentration of\ud
metals in mosses depends not only on metal deposition but also\ud
on factors such as moss species, canopy drip, precipitation, altitude,\ud
distance to the sea and the analytical technique used. However,\ud
contrasting results have been reported and the interpretation\ud
of the spatial variability of the metal accumulation in mosses\ud
remains difficult. In the presented study existing monitoring data\ud
from the European Heavy Metals in Mosses Surveys together with\ud
surface data on precipitation, elevation and land use are statistically\ud
analysed to assess factors other than emissions that have an\ud
influence on the metal accumulation in the mosses.\ud
Main Features. Inference statistics and Spearman correlation analysis\ud
were applied to examine the association of the metal accumulation\ud
and the distance of the monitoring sites to the sea as well as\ud
the altitude. Whether or not significant differences of the metal\ud
loads in the mosses exist at national borders was examined with\ud
help of the U-test after Mann and Whitney. In order to identify\ud
and rank the factors that are assumed to have an influence on the\ud
metal uptake of the mosses Classification and Regression Trees\ud
(CART) were applied.\ud
Results. No clear tendency could be derived from the results of\ud
the inference statistical calculations and the correlation analyses\ud
with regard to the distance of the monitoring site to the sea and\ud
the altitude. According to the results of the CART-analyses mainly\ud
the moss species, potential emission sources around the monitoring\ud
sites, canopy drip and precipitation have an effect on the metal\ud
bioaccumulation. Assuming that each participating country followed\ud
strictly the manual for sampling and sample preparation\ud
the results of the inference statistical calculations furthermore\ud
suggest that in most cases different techniques for digestion and\ud
analysis bias the measurements significantly.\ud
Discussion. For the first time a national monitoring data base consisting\ud
of measurement data and metadata as well as surface information\ud
on precipitation, land use and elevation was applied to examine\ud
influence factors on the metal bioaccumulation in mosses.\ud
The respective results mirror existing knowledge from other national\ud
studies to a large extend, although further analyses are necessary\ud
to affirm the findings. These analyses should include data\ud
from other national monitoring programmes and should additionally\ud
be carried out with other decision tree algorithms than CART.\ud
Conclusions. The local variability in the metal concentration in\ud
mosses can be uncovered in terms of predictors or underlying\ud
hidden causes by using CART. Ideally, such an approach should\ud
be applied across the whole of Europe. This will only be feasible\ud
if all participating countries provide additional information about\ud
site characteristics as currently is done in for example the German\ud
moss surveys.\ud
Recommendations. The UNECE Metals in Mosses Survey experimental\ud
protocol should be improved in order to reduce the observed\ud
influences, to enhance standardisation, and to strengthen\ud
the quality control. This implies the integration of sampling site\ud
describing metadata into the assessment. Furthermore, basis research\ud
is needed to test the hypothesis concerning moss speciesspecific\ud
accumulation of depositions.\ud
Perspectives. Provided that the presented results hold true in further\ud
analyses correction factors should be applied on the moss\ud
data in order to get the depicted spatial patterns and temporal\ud
trends of metal bioaccumulation unbiased. Such factors should\ud
be calculated for natural landscape units or ecoregions that are\ud
homogeneous with regard to climate, vegetation and altitud
